A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, including light and other electromagnetic waves, has enough energy to escape it.[2] The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform spacetime to form a black hole.[3][4] The boundary of no escape is called the event horizon. small question about hexadecimal in web apps
It isnt a hexadecimal. It is an UUID hash.

Depends on the web site.Most likely you are seeing an internally generated "unique id" for the media. It could be a hexadecimal representation of a UUID, or something else unique to that application or web site.40 hex digits equates to 160 binary digits (1.46e48 possible values). The set of possible values are so large that simply "guessing at random" isn't practical. You'd need an index or catalog to find out which values are legitimate.

No, not really. That 40-digit hex can be anything, but it's likely a SHA-1 hash of the file. 40 digits of hex == 20 bytes == SHA-1 hash size, which is still common to use for file hashes.File hashes are handy to ensure that a file hasn't changed. If the file changes, the hash in the file name changes, so you never have to worry about accidentally using stale cache. Without the worry of stale cache, you can cache for MUCH longer, like a year.It saves a lot of money, if you have the ability to tag your files with a hexadecimal hash digest (such as SHA-1).
No, that's usually the point. It's used to prevent enumeration.

Those 40-digit hex codes are unique IDs for media on the site, made to prevent unauthorized access. Trying to guess them is a no-go — it's against the rules and can be illegal. They're usually random and not meant to be predictable, for security reasons.

A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, including light and other electromagnetic waves, has enough energy to escape it.[2] The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform spacetime to form a black hole.[3][4] The boundary of no escape is called the event horizon. How we reduced Laravel SaaS app Database from 85% to 45%

Please don't give advice you're not qualified to give.Using PURGE BINARY LOGS BEFORE NOW() is a great way to make your replicas lose data/be out of sync.The correct approach is documented in the manual here — in short, check the slave status to see what the oldest log currently being replicated is and only purge to before that date.An better option is to set the binlog_expire_logs_seconds system variable to something approaching your maximum replica lag time (default is 30 days, you could likely set it to 1 day and reap most of the space saving benefits without any concerns). This also means that it will be automatically maintained rather than needing to periodically run the PURGE BINARY LOGS statement.On a final note, a 25GB DB is tiny in the world of data, and giving results in percentages is silly when it's not a fixed size thing you're talking about, if the DB were 2.5TB, you would've gone from 0.85% down to 0.45%, and it's highly unlikely if you were using 45% of 2.5TB that you would balloon to 85%, and even if you did, these tricks would be unlikely to yield the same result.

So the hot tips for using less disk are:Disable debugging in production.Have a log file management strategy.This is basic stuff. If you're running an app that has real user data and not doing these, you need to consider hiring some professionals.Next hot tips, slow query optimisation, indexing and partitioning...

The travel industry has very low average margins - around 2% I think - but refunds and chargebacks can have high individual values. Add to this that when travel companies go bust it can cost a lot to repatriate travellers to their home countries - which is why these companies usually need to be licensed and hold a bond with someone like ATOL.For this reason, it’s common that payment processors have a default position to not work with these companies. If your company has higher than average margins, you can potentially present a case based on that, your licensing, historical refund/chargeback rates etc and try to persuade a processor such as Stripe that you are a reliable partner.But never get involved in handling card details yourself, even encrypted.
